question: Does the pioneer transcription factor OCT3/4 (Oct4) physically interact with major chromatin-remodeling or chromatin-modifying complexes in embryonic stem cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Notably, we found that Oct4 is associated with multiple chromatin-modifying complexes with documented as well as newly proved functional significance in stem cell maintenance and somatic cell reprogramming.
content.source_2: In a quantitative interactome captured under non-crosslinked, endogenous expression conditions, OCT3/4 did not co-purify with any core chromatin-remodeling ATPases (e.g., BRG1/SMARCA4, CHD1, INO80), indicating an absence of direct interactions with major remodeling machineries in embryonic stem cells.
content.source_3: Subsequent purification of Oct4 partners Sall4, Tcfcp2l1, Dax1, and Esrrb resulted in an Oct4 interactome of 166 proteins, including transcription factors and chromatin-modifying complexes with documented roles in self-renewal, but also many factors not previously associated with the ESC network.
content.source_4: When chromatin was digested with micrococcal nuclease or DNA was competed with ethidium bromide during immunoprecipitation, all apparent associations between OCT4 and SWI/SNF, NuRD, and INO80 subunits were abolished, arguing that OCT4 does not physically interact with major chromatin remodelers but is only co-enriched via DNA.
